saberes: A. Communication.
- Basic strategies for the planning, execution, control and repair of the comprehension, production and co-production of oral, written and multimodal texts.
- Knowledge, skills and attitudes that allow detecting and collaborating in mediation activities in simple everyday situations.

- Basic communicative functions appropriate to the field and the communicative context: greeting, saying goodbye, introducing and introducing oneself; describe people, objects, and places; compare people and objects; situate events in time; locate objects, people and places in space; request and exchange information on everyday issues; give and ask for instructions and orders; offer, accept and reject help, propositions or suggestions; partially express taste or interest and basic emotions; describe present and habitual situations; narrate past events; express future events; express the opinion, the possibility, the capacity, the obligation and the prohibition.

- Contextual models and basic discursive genres in the comprehension, production and co-production of oral, written and multimodal, short and simple, literary and non-literary texts: characteristics and recognition of the context (participants and situation), expectations generated by the context; organization and structuring according to genre and textual function.

- Basic linguistic units and meanings associated with such units such as expression of the entity and its properties, quantity and quality, space and spatial relations, time and temporal relations, affirmation, negation, interrogation and exclamation, basic logical relationships.

- Lexicon of common use and interest for students related to personal identification, interpersonal relationships, nearby places and environments, leisure and free time, daily life, health and physical activity, housing and home, climate and natural environment, information technologies and communication and sustainability and responsible consumption.
- Self-confidence. The error as an instrument for improvement and a proposal for reparation.

- Basic sound, stress, rhythmic and intonation patterns, and general communicative meanings and intentions associated with these patterns. Phonemes of the foreign language and comparison with those of the mother tongue.
- Basic spelling conventions and meanings and communicative intentions associated with formats, patterns and graphic elements.

- Basic conversational conventions and strategies, in synchronous or asynchronous format, to start, maintain and end communication, take and give the floor, ask for and give clarifications and explanations, reformulate, compare and contrast, summarize, collaborate, debate, etc.
- Resources for learning and basic information search strategies: dictionaries in any medium, reference books, libraries, digital and computer resources, tools, and mobile applications.
- Identification of the authorship of the consulted sources and the contents used. Discrimination of information.

- Basic analog and digital tools for oral, written and multimodal comprehension, production and co-production; and virtual platforms for educational interaction, cooperation and collaboration (virtual classrooms, videoconferences, collaborative digital tools, etc.) for learning, communication and the development of projects with speakers or students of the foreign language.
- Graded readings of literary texts or subject matter appropriate to the age of the students as a source of linguistic enrichment.
B. Multilingualism.

- Strategies and techniques to respond effectively to a basic and specific communicative need in an understandable way, despite the limitations derived from the level of competence in the foreign language and in the other languages of the own linguistic repertoire.

- Basic strategies to identify, organize, retain, recover and creatively use linguistic units (lexicon, morphosyntax, sound patterns, etc.) from the comparison of the languages and varieties that make up the personal linguistic repertoire.
- Basic strategies and tools for self-assessment and peer-assessment, analogue and digital, individual and cooperative.
- Lexicon and commonly used expressions to understand statements about communication, language, learning and introduction to the knowledge of communication and learning tools (metalanguage).
- Basic comparison between languages based on elements of the foreign language and other languages: origin and relationships.
C. Interculturality.
- The foreign language as a means of interpersonal and international communication, a source of information and as a tool for personal enrichment.
- Interest and initiative in carrying out communicative exchanges through different media with speakers or students of the foreign language.

- Basic sociocultural and sociolinguistic aspects related to daily life, living conditions and interpersonal relationships; basic social conventions; non-verbal language, linguistic courtesy and digital etiquette; culture, customs and values of countries where the foreign language is spoken.
- Specific graded readings for learning the foreign language or based on significant literary works that reflect the idiosyncrasy and culture of the countries and territories where it is spoken.
- Basic strategies to understand and appreciate linguistic, cultural and artistic diversity, taking into account ecosocial and democratic values.
- Basic strategies for detection and action against discriminatory uses of verbal and non-verbal language.
- Geopolitical, physical and economic aspects of the countries where the foreign language is spoken.
syntactic-discursive structures
1. Greet and say goodbye, introduce and introduce yourself.
Simple formulas and greetings: How are you? Pleased to meet you! Be and have (got).
Personal pronouns. Demonstratives.
2. Describe people, objects, and places.
Be and have (got).
Present simple/present continuous.
Demonstratives. Personal pronouns.
Determiners and possessive pronouns. Prepositions and adverbs of place and distance. Possessives (pronouns and adjectives). Saxon genitive.
3. Compare people and objects.
Adjectives in positive, comparative and superlative degree. Adverbs of intensity: very, a lot, etc.
Quantity expressions: much, many, etc.
4. Place events in time.
There is/there are.
Past simple.
Present perfect.
Prepositions (for, since, just).
Adverbs: already, still, yet.
Time expressions: at that time, for a while, etc.
5. Locate objects, people and places in space.
There is/there are.
Prepositions: on, under, between, etc. Adverbs of place: there, here, etc.
6. Request and exchange information on everyday issues. More complex interrogatives: How often, How far, etc.
Adverbs of frequency: always, never, sometimes, twice a week, etc.
7. Give and ask for instructions and orders. imperatives
Modal verbs (can/could, must/have to). Expressions of courtesy: Excuse me, Pardon? Sorry? Formulas: How can I get to…?
8. Offer, accept and reject help, propositions or suggestions. Modal verbs: can, could, shall/will, should/ought to;
Expressions such as Can I help you?, Would you like…?, How/what about…? Let's... Why don't we...?
Accept and reject responses: Fine! Excellent! That's a great idea! Oh no thanks!
9. Partially express taste or interest and basic emotions. Verbs like like/dislike, love/hate, enjoy, etc.
Verbs like I feel, I know, I think…
Exclamatory: How + adjective!, What a + noun phrase!.
10. Describe current situations and habitual actions.
Present simple/present continuous.
11. Narrate past events. Past simple/past continuous. When/while.
12. Express future events.
Future simple, be going to, present continuous with future meaning. Temporary expressions: this week, next month, etc.
13. Express the opinion, the possibility, the capacity, the obligation and the prohibition. Basic expressions of opinion like I think, in my opinion, etc.
Modals: may/might, can/could, must/have to, mustn't, can't, should/ought to. Expressions like: be allowed to, be able to, be likely to, etc.
criteriosEvaluacion: 1.1 Interpret and analyze the global meaning and the specific and explicit information of brief and simple oral, written and multimodal texts on frequent and daily topics, of personal relevance and close to the experience of the students, typical of the fields of interpersonal relationships, learning, media and fiction expressed clearly and in the standard language through various media. (CCL2, CCL4, CD1, CCEC2)

1.2 Select, organize and apply in a guided way the most appropriate strategies and knowledge in everyday communicative situations to understand the general meaning, the essential information and the most relevant details of the texts; interpret non-verbal elements; and search and select information. (CCL3, CCL4, PC1, PC2, STEM1, CD1, CPSAA5)

2.1 Orally express short, simple, structured, understandable and appropriate texts for the communicative situation on daily and frequent matters, relevant to students, in order to describe, narrate and inform about specific topics, in different supports, using in a guided way verbal and non-verbal resources, as well as production planning and control strategies. (CCL1, CP1, STEM1, CD3, CPSAA1, CE3, CCEC3)

2.2 Organize and write short and understandable texts with clarity, coherence, cohesion and adaptation to the proposed communicative situation, following established guidelines, through analog and digital tools, on daily and frequent issues of relevance to students and close to their experience. (CCL1, CP1, CP2, STEM1, CD2, CD3, CPSAA5, CE3, CCEC3)

2.3 Select, organize and apply knowledge and strategies in a guided way to plan, produce and review texts that are understandable, coherent and appropriate to the communicative intentions, the contextual characteristics and the textual typology, using with the help of the most appropriate physical or digital resources depending on the task and the needs of each moment, taking into account the people to whom the text is addressed. (CCL1, CCL5, CP1, CP2, STEM1, CD2, CD3, CPSAA5, CE1, CE3, CCEC3)

2.4 Use vocabulary related to everyday matters related to one's own interests, adapting them to the communicative situation and with a variety appropriate to the level. (CCL1, PC1, PC2, CD2, CE1, CE3, CCEC3)

2.5 Describe facts and express opinions or feelings clearly orally or in writing in analog and digital contexts, exchanging appropriate information for different daily contexts of their personal, social, global, and educational environment. (CCL1, CP1, STEM1, CD2, CD3, CPSAA1, CE1, CE3)

3.1 Plan and participate in brief and simple interactive situations on everyday topics, of personal relevance and close to the experience of the students, through various supports, relying on resources such as repetition, a leisurely pace or non-verbal language, and showing empathy and respect for linguistic courtesy and digital etiquette, as well as for the different needs, ideas, concerns, initiatives and motivations of the interlocutors. (CCL1, CCL5, PC1, PC2, CPSAA3, CC3)

3.2 Select, organize and use, in a guided way and in close environments, appropriate strategies to start, maintain and end communication, take and give the floor, request and formulate clarifications and explanations. (CCL1, CCL5, CP1, STEM1, CD2, CPSAA3, CC3)

3.3 Make yourself understood in simple interventions, even if it is necessary to resort to pauses or repetitions, correcting and reformulating what you want to express and showing a cooperative and respectful attitude. (CCL1, CCL5, PC1, PC2, CPSAA1, CPSAA3, CC3)
3.4 Carry out projects in a guided way, using digital tools and working collaboratively in safe digital environments, with an open, respectful and responsible attitude. (CCL1, CCL5, STEM1, CD2, CC3)

4.1 Infer and explain texts, concepts and brief and simple communications in situations in which to attend to diversity, showing respect and empathy for the interlocutors and for the languages used, and interest in participating in the solution of problems of intercomprehension and understanding in the immediate environment, relying on various resources and supports. (CCL1, CCL5, CP2, STEM1, CD3, CPSAA1, CPSAA3, CC4, CE3, CCEC1)

4.2 Apply, in a guided way, strategies that help create bridges and facilitate the understanding and production of information and communication, appropriate to the communicative intentions, using resources and physical or digital supports depending on the needs of each moment. (CCL1, CCL5, CP1, CP2, CP3, STEM1, CD3, CPSAA1, CPSAA3, CE3)

4.3 Use mediation strategies with sufficient guidance, such as interpretation, explanation and summary of the essential, taking full advantage of and organizing the mediator's previous resources and relying on all those who can serve of help. (CCL5, CP1, CP2, CD3, CPSAA1, CPSAA3, CC4)
5.1 Compare and contrast the similarities and differences between different languages, reflecting on their functioning in a progressively autonomous way. (CCL3, CPSAA5, CC2)

5.2 Use and differentiate knowledge and strategies to improve the ability to communicate and learn the foreign language with the support of other participants and analog and digital supports. (CCL1, CP2, STEM1, CD2, CD3, CPSAA1, CPSAA5) 5.3 Identify and record, following models, the progress and difficulties in learning the foreign language, selecting in a guided way the most effective strategies to overcome these difficulties and progress in the learning, carrying out self-assessment and peer-assessment activities, such as those proposed in the European Language Portfolio (PEL) or in a learning diary, making those progress and difficulties explicit and sharing them. (CPSAA1, CPSAA4, CPSAA5, CC2)

6.1 Act empathetically and respectfully in intercultural situations, building links between different languages and cultures and rejecting any type of discrimination, prejudice and stereotype in everyday communicative contexts. (CCL5, CP2, CP3, CPSAA1, CPSAA3, CC2, CC3, CCEC1, CCEC2)

6.2 Accept and adapt to the linguistic, literary, cultural and artistic diversity typical of countries where the foreign language is spoken, recognizing it as a source of personal enrichment and showing interest in sharing cultural and linguistic elements that promote sustainability and democracy. (CCL4, CCL5, CP2, CP3, CPSAA1, CPSAA3, CC2, CC3, CCEC1, CCEC2)

6.3 Apply, in a guided way, strategies to explain and appreciate linguistic, literary, cultural and artistic diversity, attending to ecosocial and democratic values and respecting the principles of justice, equity and equality. (CCL4, CCL5, CP3, CPSAA1, CPSAA3, CC2, CC3, CCEC1, CCEC2)
